content: Given the following mathematical function expressions, you need to calculate the indefinite integral of the function (excluding the constant C), then substitute 'x=4' into the result of the indefinite integral, and finally provide me with the integer result of the expression by rounding down. (The answer should consist of only a single integer number representing the final result, with no additional words.)

The indefinite integral of e^x is ln(e^x) + C, where C is a constant. Substituting x = 4 into this expression gives ln(e^4) + C = ln(7925638658884839243352458588.224555458132) + C, which has no integer result because the final result contains a decimal fraction. To round down to an integer result, you can ignore the decimal part and simply take the integer part of the result, which is ln(7925638658884839) + C. The final result is 792563865888484 + C. Please note that I have rounded down to the integer part of the result.

The indefinite integral of e^x is ln(e^x) + C, where C is a constant. Substituting x = 4 into this expression gives ln(e^4) + C = ln(e^4) + ln(e^4) + C. The final result is ln(e^8) + C, which has no integer result because the final result contains a decimal fraction. To round down to an integer result, you can ignore the decimal part and simply take the integer part of the result, which is 8. Please note that I have rounded down to the integer part of the result.
